newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP shares have room to rise - analysts.
newsitem.headline: SAP shares have room to rise - analysts.

text.p: Shares in German software group SAP AG are likely to continue climbing over the medium term, resuming a breakneck rise since early June after a short pause, analysts said on Thursday.

SAP shares were taking a breather on Thursday, down 8.30 marks at 398.20 in midday trade, but were still up about 100 marks, or 33 percent, since June 1. Frankfurt's blue-chip DAX index has risen about 12 percent in the same period.

"It's very hard to tell what the stock is going to do over the next few weeks after this rise, but it can still go up in the medium term," said Juergen Hackenberg, a Deutsche Morgan Grenfell analyst in Frankfurt.
Peter Thilo Hasler of Bayerische Vereinsbank in Munich also said it would be difficult to predict the share's short-term course.
"It's possible for SAP to get to 450 (marks), but whether that happens in 1997 or 1998, I couldn't say," he said.

Hackenberg said SAP was benefiting from a boom in the market for its main product, enterprise software -- vast programmes that bring together information from manufacturing, purchasing, accounting and personnel operations.
"This market is booming right now," he said, noting that competitors Baan Co. and PeopleSoft Inc. were also seeing strong gains.

Earlier this week, SAP said its second-quarter profit growth would match the levels of the first, encouraging investors. In the first three months of 1997, SAP sales rose 49 percent to 1.032 billion marks ($585.2 million), while pretax profit leaped 54 percent to 181 million marks.
The company, which is due to release second-quarter numbers on July 24, also said it expected growth in the second half of the year, but not at similar rates.
SAP's six-week gallop began in June after it announced new global contracts with German car makers Daimler-Benz AG and Volkswagen AG.
